div.l: The Grettest clerkes ben not the wisest men
As whilome to the wolf thus spake the mare
Of all her arte ne counte I nought a tare
Oute at the dorre he gothe full pⁱrively
When that he sawe his tyme shortly
He loketh vp and doun̄ till he hath founde
The Clerkes horse there he stode bounde
Be hynde the mylne vnder a lef selle
And to the horse he gothe faire and welle
He strypeth of the brydell right anoone
And when the horse was lawse he gan to gone
Towarde the Fenne there wilde mares ronne
Forth wᵗith through thick and thynne
This mylnere gothe ageyn and no worde seide
But dothe his note and with the clerkes pleyde
Till that her corne was faire and wele y grounde
And when the mele was saket and wele bounde
This Iohn gothe oute and fynde his hors a way
And gan to Crye harowe and wele a way
Oure horse is stole Aleyn for goddis bones
Step on thy fote come on man all at oones
Aleyn oure wardeyn hath his palfray lorne
This aleyn all forgeteth mele and corne
All was it oute of his mynde housbondrye
What wicked way is he gone gan he crye
The wyf came rennyng Inwarde wᵗith a renne
She saide allas youre horse gothe to the Fenne
With wilde mares as faste as he may goo
Vnthanke come on his hande that bonde hym so
And he that bett̉er shulde haue knytte the reyne
Aleyn qduod Iohn allas for criftes payne
Lygge doun̄ thy swerde and I shall myne also
He is full wight god wote as is a roo
Be goddis herte he shall not scape vs bothe
Why ne hadde thou put the Capill in the lathe
Ilhayle Aleyn bi god thou is fonne
Towarde the Fenne is bothe aleyn and Iohn
This Cely clerkes spedde hem anoone
And when the myln̉er sawe that they were gone
He half a busshell of floure he hath take
And bade his wyf to knede it in a Cake
He seide I trowe the clerkes ben a ferde
Yite cane a myln̉er make a clerkes berde
